page.title: 08Barnby in the W.River Witham
page.content: About 10 years ago the river bed was lowered and flood banks raised. All the riverside trees were removed and not replaced. Regular weedkilling by the Severn Trent Water Authority reduced the Witham near Barnby to no more than a drainage ditch. Fortunately the use of weedkillers seems to have ceased and the river banks are recovering rapidly. The soil disturbance has allowed dormant seeds to germinate and the variety of plants has improved. The Witham is again beginning to look more like a river and less a canal. The water is probably cleaner now than it has been for several centuries. The main problem, now common to most English rivers, is excessive growth of weed due to agricultural fertilizers which reach the river through the ever increasing number of field drains.
